rows.question_text: What challenge did you have when trying to spend one-on-one time with your child?

question_text.eng: What challenge did you have when trying to spend one-on-one time with your child?

text_challenge_1.eng: I did not have enough time.

reply_challenge_1.eng:
It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else.

‚ú®Think of a time each day that you could spare 5 minutes. You can even make household chores into a game to do together.

Use the time that you and your child are already sharing, like going to school, picking them up, waking them up or saying goodnight  before they sleep. 

You will find playful activities in the App.

text_challenge_2.eng: My child did not want to spend one-on-one time with me.

reply_challenge_2.eng:
It can hurt when your child does not want to spend one-on-one time with you.

Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? In the morning? Right before bedtime?

Try again so that your child can see that you care and want to spend this time with them.

text_challenge_3.eng: All my child wanted to do was watch YouTube or play with their tablet.

reply_challenge_3.eng:
üì∫ Children often want to spend time using electronic devices.

You could watch or play on the device with them.

Caring about their interests is a great start!

 Once you begin spending time together you can suggest another activity.

You can find playful activities in the App.

text_challenge_4.eng: My child wanted to do activities that I could not do.

reply_challenge_4.eng:
If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to do, you could watch them.

üèÅ You could describe what they are doing like a sports announcer.

You can also express enthusiasm by clapping, smiling, or offering a thumbs-up.

Praise them while they do it!

text_challenge_5.eng: My child chose a competitive activity. I won and then they got angry.

reply_challenge_5.eng:
‚öΩ Competitive games can be hard for children (and adults!) if they don‚Äôt like losing.

üèÜ When they have calmed down, talk with your boys and girls about what winning well and losing well might look like.

üìù Suggest other activities that you can do to work together instead of against each other.

You can find playful activities in the App.

text_challenge_6.eng: All my children wanted one-on-one time at the same time.

reply_challenge_6.eng:
It can be difficult to spend one-on-one time with each of your children when you have more than one.

If possible, you can ask an adult or older sibling to look after your other children while you spend one-on-one time with your child

‚è∞ Think of when it would be easier to spend one-on-one time with each of your children

You can also spend one-on-one time with all of your children at once! If you do, make sure all can participate in one-on-one time.

You can find playful activities in the App.

reply_challenge_7.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: What challenge did you have when trying to talk about feelings with your child?

question_text.eng: What challenge did you have when trying to talk about feelings with your child?

text_challenge_1.eng: I did not have enough time.

reply_challenge_1.eng: It‚Äôs okay! Life gets busy. Try setting aside just 5 minutes at the same time every day. You‚Äôre doing great by making the effort to connect!

text_challenge_2.eng: My child did not want to share their feelings

reply_challenge_2.eng:
It‚Äôs normal for children to be hesitant about sharing their feelings, especially when it‚Äôs new. 

Keep being patient and offer chances to talk. You‚Äôre on the right track by modelling it with an ‚ÄòI feel‚Ä¶‚Äô statement like ‚ÄòI feel happy!

text_challenge_3.eng: I felt uncomfortable talking about my feelings

reply_challenge_3.eng:
It‚Äôs okay to feel that way! Start small and use ‚ÄòI feel‚Ä¶‚Äô to ease into it.

 You‚Äôre taking a brave step in being open, and that‚Äôs something to be proud of!

text_challenge_4.eng: Others in the household don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a good idea to talk about emotions.

reply_challenge_4.eng:
It‚Äôs understandable that not everyone will be  convinced right away. 

Talk with them about why it could be helpful and encourage them to try. 

You‚Äôre doing an important job by advocating for open communication!

text_challenge_5.eng: Others in the household don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a good idea to talk about negative emotions

reply_challenge_5.eng:
It‚Äôs okay to feel unsure about this. 

Discuss why talking about negative emotions can be healthy, and encourage them to give it a try. 

You‚Äôre showing great care by fostering emotional awareness!

text_challenge_6.eng: I don‚Äôt know how to name some of the feelings I am experiencing.

reply_challenge_6.eng:
That‚Äôs okay! It can be hard to find the right words.

Try combining the names of emotions you do know. 

You‚Äôre doing a great job by simply acknowledging your feelings!

reply_challenge_7.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.reply_challenge_7: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: Did you have any challenges when trying to play with your child?

question_text.eng: Did you have any challenges when trying to play with your child?

text_challenge_1.eng: I don‚Äôt have time to play with my girl or boy.

reply_challenge_1.eng:
It is okay to feel that way. But there are many small ways to spend time with your child!

You can interact with your child while doing something else. For example, you can ask your child to describe the colours and objects they see around them while you are walking together or riding in the car.

Your child will appreciate the attention you are giving, even for a short while.

text_challenge_2.eng: My child is not interested in playing with me.

reply_challenge_2.eng:
You may feel hurt because your child doesn't want to spend time with you. It is important to give them their space, be patient and listen to what is happening to her or him. Open yourself to opportunities to play with them another time.

Sometimes, your child just needs time to engage with you. It helps to remain calm, patient, and kind while you try to connect with your child.

As girls and boys grow, they may want independence from you. That‚Äôs normal! You can support them to find friends based on their interests.

text_challenge_3.eng: My child keeps getting hurt from exploring or making new friends.

reply_challenge_3.eng:
It must be hard to see your child getting injured or feeling sad often.

Children learn and grow from making mistakes. It is an important part of the development of your girl and boy. They will be safe as long as you are aware of their activities and you can prevent anything dangerous from happening.

 Build your child‚Äôs confidence in their abilities, values, and appearance so that they are comfortable trying new things.

Encourage them to safely try out fun activities with other girls, boys or adults. Praise them when they do it well!

Let your child know that you trust them to be safe and follow the rules that you have set.

text_challenge_4.eng: My child likes competitive activities but gets angry when they lose or need to share the win.

reply_challenge_4.eng:
‚öΩ Competitive games can be hard for girls and boys (even adults!) if they don‚Äôt like losing or sharing.

üèÜ When they have calmed down, talk with your child about what winning well and losing well might look like.

üìù Suggest other activities that you can do to work together instead of against each other.

You can find playful activities in the App.

reply_challenge_5.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: What challenge did you face when trying to praise your child?

question_text.eng: What challenge did you face when trying to praise your child?

reply_challenge_1.eng: It can sometimes be hard to remember to praise our children. Next time you spend one-on-one time with your child, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say, ‚ÄúThank you for spending time with me!‚Äù

text_challenge_2.eng: My child was surprised or suspicious.

reply_challenge_2.eng: Remember, it takes some time for your child to get used to seeing you praise them. The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!

text_challenge_3.eng: My child did not like it.

reply_challenge_3.eng: It happens ‚Äì just be patient. Try to remember to ask your child to decide what activity they would like to do with you. This will make it more likely that they enjoy the activity, too.

reply_challenge_4.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.reply_challenge_1: It can sometimes be hard to remember to praise our children. Next time you spend one-on-one time with your child, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say, ‚ÄúThank you for spending time with me!‚Äù
rows.text_challenge_2: My child was surprised or suspicious.
rows.reply_challenge_2: Remember, it takes some time for your child to get used to seeing you praise them. The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!

rows.reply_challenge_4: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: What challenge did you face when trying to give POSITIVE, SPECIFIC, and REALISTIC instructions to your child?

question_text.eng: What challenge did you face when trying to give POSITIVE, SPECIFIC, and REALISTIC instructions to your child?

text_challenge_1.eng: My child did not follow my instructions even if I used the tips

reply_challenge_1.eng: Children need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient. Try again. Remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction.

text_challenge_2.eng: It is hard to remember to use positive words when giving instructions.

reply_challenge_2.eng: This is difficult to remember for everyone at first! Try to take a breath before giving an instruction. Also, remember to be gentle with yourself when you forget. It happens to everyone!

text_challenge_3.eng: I shouted at my child when they behaved negatively instead of giving them a positive instruction for what they should do.

reply_challenge_3.eng: It‚Äôs difficult to give instructions in a calm way when we are still angry. Try to find a time when you are calm or to use a calming strategy like Take a Pause before you introduce a positive instruction.

reply_challenge_4.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.text_challenge_1: My child did not follow my instructions even if I used the tips
rows.reply_challenge_1: Children need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient. Try again. Remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction.
rows.text_challenge_2: It is hard to remember to use positive words when giving instructions.
rows.reply_challenge_2: This is difficult to remember for everyone at first! Try to take a breath before giving an instruction. Also, remember to be gentle with yourself when you forget. It happens to everyone!

rows.reply_challenge_4: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: What challenge did you face when trying to make a rule and routine together?

question_text.eng: What challenge did you face when trying to make a rule and routine together?

text_challenge_1.eng: My child could not agree on one specific rule or routine.

reply_challenge_1.eng:
üìñ When creating rules, it is important to think about the age of each child so you can come up with routines that are fair for their age.

‚è∞ This is most important for bedtime, electronic device use, and the chores they are responsible for.

 Try to agree on a small and meaningful incentive that can motivate your child to follow the rule. Consider options like playing a 15-minute board game with the family, choosing the food for the day, or enjoying a 30-minute trip to the beach.

What other ideas come to mind?

text_challenge_2.eng: My child felt it was unfair that they had to follow the rule while I didn‚Äôt have to follow it.

reply_challenge_2.eng:
Our children learn best from us.

The more we follow the rules, the more they will follow the rules too.

You can adapt the rule to make sure that it is something everyone can follow.

text_challenge_3.eng: I felt uncomfortable because I think an adult should create the rule, not my child.

reply_challenge_3.eng:
When we create rules together with our children, we build trust and an open relationship with them.

üîë The rules we set will be more realistic and your child will be more willing and able to follow the rules.

Think about the valuable lessons you‚Äôll be teaching your child, such as working together and taking the initiative.

text_challenge_4.eng: We were not able to stick to the rule.

reply_challenge_4.eng: The rule needs to be specific and realistic. Make sure to have a rule that can be kept easily, like having one meal together every week instead of every night. Do you need to be more flexible about the rules?

reply_challenge_5.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.reply_challenge_5: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: What was difficult when managing your child's challenging behaviour?

question_text.eng: What was difficult when managing your child's challenging behaviour?

text_challenge_1.eng: I can‚Äôt redirect my child to a positive behaviour when they are misbehaving.

reply_challenge_1.eng:
üå± Next time, try to catch the misbehaviour early on, before it sets in or gets worse.

üëÇ Talk to them about this behaviour when both of you feel calmer.

‚≠ê Remember to praise your child when they behave well.

text_challenge_2.eng: I get too angry at my child and find it difficult to be positive with them when they are no longer misbehaving.

reply_challenge_2.eng:
üå± It is normal to sometimes get angry at our children when they are misbehaving, especially when they are driving us crazy.

‚è∏ Next time, when you are overwhelmed or angry, take a deep breath. If needed, walk away from the situation before you react. 

Remember, your child's behaviour isn‚Äôt meant to hurt you. As children, it's normal for them to explore their limits. 

‚òÄÔ∏è Later, find something small and clear that child is doing and you wish they could do more of. Then, praise them when they do it.

text_challenge_3.eng: My Child misbehaves all the time.

reply_challenge_3.eng:
üå± It is normal to sometimes get angry at our children when they are misbehaving, especially when they are driving us crazy.

‚è∏ Next time, when you are overwhelmed or angry, take a deep breath. If needed, walk away from the situation before you react. 

Remember, your child's behaviour isn‚Äôt meant to hurt you. As children, it's normal for them to explore their limits. 

Later, find something small and clear that your children is doing and you wish they could do more of. Then, praise them when they do it. 

‚òÄÔ∏è Later, find something small and clear that your child is doing and you wish they could do more of. Then, praise them when they do it.

text_challenge_4.eng: I got very angry with my child and shouted at them.

reply_challenge_4.eng:
üå∑ It is normal to sometimes get angry at our children when they are misbehaving, especially when they are driving us crazy. The important thing is how we manage that anger and respond to them.

‚è∏ First, take a pause. 

When you are overwhelmed or angry, take a deep breath. If needed, walk away from the situation before you react. 

Remember, your child's behaviour isn‚Äôt meant to hurt you. As children, it's normal for them to explore their limits. 
üíö Be kind to yourself. You are both learning and it‚Äôs okay not to get it right all the time.

üå± When you feel calmer, you could apologise to your child for shouting and remind them that you love them. 

üéà Repeat the core message of what you were trying to say in a calmer way.

text_challenge_5.eng: Ignoring my child‚Äôs whining or tantrums is not working. They are still happening a lot.

reply_challenge_5.eng:
Here are 3Ô∏è‚É£ three tips to remember if your child‚Äôs behaviour is persisting:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Your child will act out negatively to get attention if they are not getting positive attention. Try to praise your child‚Äôs positive behaviour when you see it.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Remain consistent when ignoring behaviours. Inconsistency may confuse children and reinforce negative attention seeking behaviours. 

3Ô∏è‚É£Consider whether the behaviour is age appropriate.Your child may be too young for difficult tasks, like remaining quiet while you are talking to a friend. 

Remember that building a positive relationship with your child and giving your child positive attention when they are behaving well is the best way to reduce negative behaviours!

reply_challenge_6.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.text_challenge_1: I can‚Äôt redirect my child to a positive behaviour when they are misbehaving.
rows.reply_challenge_1:
üå± Next time, try to catch the misbehaviour early on, before it sets in or gets worse.

üëÇ Talk to them about this behaviour when both of you feel calmer.

‚≠ê Remember to praise your child when they behave well.

Remember, your child's behaviour isn‚Äôt meant to hurt you. As children, it's normal for them to explore their limits. 

‚òÄÔ∏è Later, find something small and clear that child is doing and you wish they could do more of. Then, praise them when they do it.

Later, find something small and clear that your children is doing and you wish they could do more of. Then, praise them when they do it.

When you are overwhelmed or angry, take a deep breath. If needed, walk away from the situation before you react. 

Remember, your child's behaviour isn‚Äôt meant to hurt you. As children, it's normal for them to explore their limits. 
üíö Be kind to yourself. You are both learning and it‚Äôs okay not to get it right all the time.

üå± When you feel calmer, you could apologise to your child for shouting and remind them that you love them. 

üéà Repeat the core message of what you were trying to say in a calmer way.
rows.text_challenge_5: Ignoring my child‚Äôs whining or tantrums is not working. They are still happening a lot.
rows.reply_challenge_5:
Here are 3Ô∏è‚É£ three tips to remember if your child‚Äôs behaviour is persisting:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Your child will act out negatively to get attention if they are not getting positive attention. Try to praise your child‚Äôs positive behaviour when you see it.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Remain consistent when ignoring behaviours. Inconsistency may confuse children and reinforce negative attention seeking behaviours. 

3Ô∏è‚É£Consider whether the behaviour is age appropriate.Your child may be too young for difficult tasks, like remaining quiet while you are talking to a friend. 

Remember that building a positive relationship with your child and giving your child positive attention when they are behaving well is the best way to reduce negative behaviours!
rows.reply_challenge_6: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: What challenge did you face when trying to introduce a consequence together?

question_text.eng: What challenge did you face when trying to introduce a consequence together?

text_challenge_1.eng: I got very angry when my child broke the rule.

reply_challenge_1.eng:
When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. 

Next time your child makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!

text_challenge_2.eng: My child got very angry with me after I gave the consequence.

reply_challenge_2.eng: Try talking to them and discussing why the rule is important to follow in the first place. You may also want to open up the discussion to them in order to make sure that the consequence seems fair and realistic.

text_challenge_3.eng: I introduced the consequence without first discussing it with my child.

reply_challenge_3.eng: When we establish a consequence together with our child, the consequence will be more realistic, and our child will be more willing and able to follow the rule.

text_challenge_4.eng: I forgot to follow through with the consequence.

reply_challenge_4.eng: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.

text_challenge_5.eng: Even with the consequence, my child still does not follow the rule.

reply_challenge_5.eng:
If your child keeps breaking rules, you might need to spend more positive time with them. 

Try to keep going with your other goals ‚Äì like self-care, one-on-one time, and praise. All these skills will help your child feel more loved and secure‚Ä¶ and make you less stressed!

text_challenge_6.eng: My child suggested being hit as a negative consequence.

reply_challenge_6.eng:
Children can be used to seeing hitting as the only possible consequence for breaking rules. 

Brainstorm some calm consequences with them that could help them understand that they have done something wrong. These will be more effective and will set positive examples!

reply_challenge_7.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: What challenge did you face when trying to resolve the problem with your child?

question_text.eng: What challenge did you face when trying to resolve the problem with your child?

text_challenge_1.eng: I forgot the steps of problem-solving.

reply_challenge_1.eng: It takes some practice to use all four steps of problem-solving. Next time a problem comes up, look at the four steps together with your child ‚Äì it will make a big difference!

text_challenge_2.eng: I started with the solutions right away.

reply_challenge_2.eng: When we have a problem, we always want to get to the quickest end result and can forget about the steps. To come up with the best solution together, it is helpful to first have a full understanding of the problem and the different solutions.

text_challenge_3.eng: We could not agree on a solution to try out and we got into an argument.

reply_challenge_3.eng: Sometimes it can be difficult to agree with everyone in the family, especially if everyone is not yet calm. You could agree to try one solution first and then another. Also, if you get stuck, try to get together later to agree on the solution together.

text_challenge_4.eng: I got angry when the problem came up and I forgot to use the problem-solving steps.

reply_challenge_4.eng: When a problem comes up, we all get angry or stressed sometimes. Remember, when you feel angry or stressed, you can take a pause to help you stay calm and then solve the problem you are facing.

text_challenge_5.eng: My child got angry and did not want to talk about the problem.

reply_challenge_5.eng: Your child might be too overwhelmed to deal with the problem right away. Recognise and name their emotions and create a time later in the day or week to discuss and solve the problem together. By giving your child time, the problem can be solved well.

reply_challenge_6.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!

rows.question_text: What challenge did you face when trying to take care of yourself?

question_text.eng: What challenge did you face when trying to take care of yourself?

reply_challenge_1.eng: It is normal to forget to take care of ourselves, especially when we are very busy. But it can make a big difference in our ability to cope with stress. Even doing something small like making time for quiet reflection or treating yourself to something nice can really help. Try to do it today!

text_challenge_2.eng: I felt guilty taking time for myself.

reply_challenge_2.eng: It‚Äôs easy to feel like you need to constantly be there for family or friends. Next time you feel that pressure, remind yourself that setting boundaries and taking time for yourself isn‚Äôt selfish ‚Äì it actually helps you be more present and supportive for others.

text_challenge_3.eng: I treated myself to something nice but still felt tired and stressed.

reply_challenge_3.eng: Even with treating yourself, you can still feel tired and stressed. Next time you feel burnt out, try balancing nice treats for yourself with things like meditation, exercise, or spending time outside. These activities can help refresh your energy in a deeper way.

text_challenge_4.eng: I felt overwhelmed by all the self-care options.

reply_challenge_4.eng: It‚Äôs easy to get lost with so many choices out there. Try to keep it simple by starting with one or two things you enjoy. You don‚Äôt have to do everything at once!

reply_challenge_5.eng: It can be frustrating when you don‚Äôt feel better right away. Next time this happens, remember that self-care is a long-term investment. Stick with it, and over time, you‚Äôll start to feel the benefits!

text_challenge_6.eng: I struggled to disconnect from work or social media.

reply_challenge_6.eng: With everything so connected, it‚Äôs tough to unplug and relax. Next time you feel overwhelmed, try setting boundaries by turning off notifications or scheduling some internet-free time. It‚Äôll help you recharge and feel more refreshed!

reply_challenge_7.eng: If you‚Äôre facing a different challenge, feel free to bring it up during the home activity discussion in the next session. We‚Äôre here to support each other!
